text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH1

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH1

text: GUIDANCE NOTE ON DATA SECURITY IN
label: HH1

text: OPERATIONAL DATA MANAGEMENT
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH1

text: •	 Data security is a key component of data responsibility – the safe, ethical and effective
label: BODY

text: management of data for humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: •	 Two common threats to data security in humanitarian action are digital surveillance and
label: BODY

text: interception, and unauthorized or malicious activity.
label: BODY

text: •	 Humanitarian actors face many challenges related to data security, including device and
label: BODY

text: application vulnerabilities, poorly secured networks, metadata exposure, physical vulnerabilities,
label: BODY

text: staff capacity and error, and managing sensitive data.
label: BODY

text: •	 A lack of robust data security undermines the ability to deliver assistance and protection to
label: BODY

text: affected people, maintain duty of care for staff, and operate effectively in complex environments.
label: BODY

text: •	 Data security requires both individual action and broader organizational engagement and
label: BODY

text: investment. This includes adopting relevant policies, guidelines and risk-related mitigation
label: BODY

text: procedures, investing in responsible data management, and promoting actions for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility among staff and partners.
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH1

text: Data security is a key component of data responsibility – the safe, ethical and effective management of
label: BODY

text: data for humanitarian response. It entails a set of physical, technological and procedural measures that
label: BODY

text: safeguard the confidentiality, integrity and availability of data, and prevent its accidental or intentional,
label: BODY

text: unlawful or otherwise unauthorized loss, destruction, alteration, acquisition or disclosure.1
label: BODY

text: Digital technologies such as mobile apps, web-based platforms, and biometric registration systems
label: BODY

text: can improve humanitarian action, but they can also increase the risk of data interception, tracking and
label: BODY

text: unauthorized access. Critical incidents such as the cyberattack on ICRC servers containing data related
label: BODY

text: to the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement's Restoring Family Links services2 have shown that the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector needs to prepare for and respond to major data security breaches and related threats.
label: BODY

text: A lack of robust data security undermines the ability to deliver assistance and protection to affected
label: BODY

text: people, maintain duty of care for staff, and operate responsibly in complex humanitarian environments.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and staff must understand vulnerabilities related to data security and
label: BODY

text: implement appropriate actions to mitigate risk. This is particularly important in conflict environments.
label: BODY

text: 1   IASC, 2021. Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: 2   ICRC, 2022. ICRC cyber-attack: Sharing our analysis.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: OCTOBER 2022
label: BODY

text: 3   Operational data management entails the collection or receipt, storage, processing, analysis, sharing, use, and retention and destruction of data
label: BODY

text: and information by humanitarian actors. IASC, 2021. Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: 4   Privacy International and ICRC, 2018. The Humanitarian Metadata Problem - Doing No Harm in the Digital Era.
label: BODY

text: 5   Privacy International, 2020. Privacy shouldn't be a luxury; also Privacy International, 2019. Buying a smartphone on the cheap? Privacy might
label: BODY

text: be the price you have to pay.
label: BODY

text: This Guidance Note presents common threats to data security and vulnerabilities in operational data
label: BODY

text: management, and offers a set of recommended actions to improve data security in humanitarian settings.3
label: BODY

text: COMMON THREATS TO DATA SECURITY
label: HH1

text: Two common threats to data security in humanitarian action are digital surveillance and interception, and
label: BODY

text: unauthorized or malicious activity.
label: BODY

text: •	 Digital surveillance and interception: Targeted surveillance, often enabled by telecommunications
label: HH1

text: service providers subject to interception requests, may allow state law enforcement and security
label: BODY

text: agencies to access/intercept communications. State and non-State actors alike may also deploy covert
label: BODY

text: surveillance tools, such as masquerading as legitimate cell phone towers known as ’IMSI-catchers’,
label: BODY

text: to support eavesdropping on mobile phone communications. Beyond targeted surveillance, many
label: BODY

text: social media platforms collect information on their users, and this data is vulnerable to the same
label: BODY

text: level of exploitation as any other data. Users often have little to no say in accepting updates to the
label: BODY

text: data processing policies, and are often unaware of what data is being generated and processed by
label: BODY

text: the platforms they use or who has access to their data. The abundance of information that can be
label: BODY

text: obtained, inferred or derived from social media data has become increasingly popular with both
label: BODY

text: private and public parties for surveillance and other non-humanitarian objectives.4
label: BODY

text: •	 Unauthorized or malicious activity: Phishing attacks that convince individuals to click a link in
label: HH1

text: communications that appear to come from trusted sources can enable remote access to a device
label: BODY

text: or compromise its contents. Malware may be installed on a device remotely or from compromised
label: BODY

text: links sent through messaging applications, emails and attachments. Less technical approaches,
label: BODY

text: such as theft or impersonation via social engineering, also pose a serious threat to individuals and
label: BODY

text: organizations.
label: BODY

text: The vulnerabilities described below increase the likelihood of these threats.
label: BODY

text: COMMON VULNERABILITIES IN OPERATIONAL DATA MANAGEMENT
label: HH1

text: While data management varies by context and organization, there are several common vulnerabilities faced
label: BODY

text: by humanitarian actors. Humanitarians should assess and reduce these vulnerabilities to minimize the
label: BODY

text: exposure of affected people and staff to threats and potential harm.
label: BODY

text: 1.	Device and application vulnerabilities
label: HH1

text: Using tools or software not approved or vetted by your organization carries a range of risks related to data
label: BODY

text: security. Similarly, outdated or poorly configured software can be exploited for surveillance purposes by
label: BODY

text: allowing attackers to gain control of a device through inadequate security controls.
label: BODY

text: In addition, mobile devices often have a number of applications that enable surveillance by supporting
label: BODY

text: activity and content tracking, and transmitting geolocation and other metadata to third parties. This applies
label: BODY

text: particularly to free applications, which are often predicated on a business model that exploits personal
label: BODY

text: data.5 The default settings of applications may also contain inherent vulnerabilities such as defaulting
label: BODY

text: message encryption to off, defaulting cloud back-ups to on or the use of conference recording functionality,
label: BODY

text: which result in conversations being stored on third-party servers.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: OCTOBER 2022
label: BODY

text: 6   Privacy International and ICRC, 2018. The Humanitarian Metadata Problem - Doing No Harm in the Digital Era.
label: BODY

text: 7    Both personal and non-personal data can be sensitive. For more information, see IASC, 2021. Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: 2.	Poorly secured networks
label: HH1

text: Using public or open Wi-Fi networks (i.e., those without a password) may expose humanitarians to
label: BODY

text: surveillance and may also lead to intrusion, such as unauthorized parties joining group chats or online
label: BODY

text: meetings. This vulnerability can also arise when an organization has not properly configured its own
label: BODY

text: servers, routers and services. The default settings are often overly permissive and may allow attackers to
label: BODY

text: gain access to devices and networks. The aim of this type of intrusion can be to identify and profile devices
label: BODY

text: and users of a network, their geographic location, the people they have communicated with, and even the
label: BODY

text: content of the communication.
label: BODY

text: 3.	Metadata exposure
label: HH1

text: All digital activities leave digital footprints, often referred to as metadata, on devices, servers and network
label: BODY

text: infrastructure. Metadata describes information about the data in question. For example, when sending
label: BODY

text: an email, the metadata would include the time sent and the IP addresses of recipient and sender.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations passively generate metadata through internal communications, exchanges
label: BODY

text: with people affected by crises, and during programme implementation and monitoring.6 Access to such
label: BODY

text: metadata can be as intrusive and revealing as access to any other data. It can reveal information about
label: BODY

text: individuals such as their location and recent activities which can enable re-identification and targeting by
label: BODY

text: malicious actors.
label: BODY

text: 4.	Physical vulnerabilities
label: HH1

text: There are a number of physical vulnerabilities that might lead to unauthorized access to data and
label: BODY

text: information by malicious actors. For example, staff might encounter checkpoints at which they are required
label: BODY

text: to hand over devices and documents. There is also a risk of physical surveillance: anyone within the vicinity
label: BODY

text: of a meeting with an interlocutor could overhear discussions or deliberately listen-in to the conversation.
label: BODY

text: Finally, devices are at greater risk of being lost or stolen when they are taken out of secured office
label: BODY

text: environments.
label: BODY

text: 5.	Staff capacity and error
label: HH1

text: Poor practices and inconsistent application of data security measures can exacerbate existing
label: BODY

text: vulnerabilities or create new ones. Staff might be unaware of the vulnerabilities related to data security
label: BODY

text: and how to mitigate the associated risks. Resource and time constraints might also have negative effects
label: BODY

text: on how staff handle data when prioritizing other areas of work. For example, staff may share sensitive data
label: BODY

text: without encrypting the file (i.e., requiring a password to open it) thereby increasing the risk of inadvertently
label: BODY

text: exposing the data.
label: BODY

text: 6.	Managing sensitive data
label: HH1

text: Sensitive data, such as data from household surveys, needs assessments and other forms of microdata,
label: BODY

text: makes up an increasingly significant volume of data in the humanitarian sector. While this type of data is
label: BODY

text: critical to humanitarian action, it can cause significant harm to individuals or organizations if accessed
label: BODY

text: without proper authorization. Managing sensitive data exacerbates other vulnerabilities by increasing the
label: BODY

text: severity of potential harm. It can also increase the likelihood of targeted attacks, including interception and
label: BODY

text: unauthorized access.7
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: OCTOBER 2022
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDED ACTIONS FOR DATA SECURITY
label: HH1

text: Humanitarians should take the following actions to improve data security in their work.
label: BODY

text: Understand the risks in your environment
label: HH1

text: •	 Identify and assess risks by conducting a Data Impact Assessment (DIA).8 DIAs provide an understanding
label: BODY

text: of the potential consequences of a data management activity.
label: BODY

text: •	 Redesign or cancel an activity if the foreseeable risks of data management outweigh the intended
label: BODY

text: benefits.
label: BODY

text: •	 Regularly consult relevant news, briefings and security reports to inform the understanding of risks in
label: BODY

text: your environment.
label: BODY

text: •	 Adapt your approach and choices to the situation. A tool or technology might be appropriate in one
label: BODY

text: context, but unsuitable in another.
label: BODY

text: Practice good password management
label: HH1

text: •	 Secure your devices and accounts with strong passwords that include numbers, capital and lowercase
label: BODY

text: letters, and symbols with at least 16+ characters per password.
label: BODY

text: •	 Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all accounts.
label: BODY

text: •	 Do not reuse the same password for multiple accounts and update passwords regularly (unless MFA is
label: BODY

text: being used).
label: BODY

text: •	 Do not store your passwords physically (on notes) or digitally (in a file on your device) and do not share
label: BODY

text: your password with others.
label: BODY

text: •	 Do not enable the ’Remember Me’ functionality in applications and browsers.
label: BODY

text: •	 Use a password manager, preferably one recommended, approved or managed by your organization.
label: BODY

text: •	 Use a password leak monitoring service to regularly check whether your password has been
label: BODY

text: compromised.
label: BODY

text: •	 Change your passwords on all accounts immediately if your device is lost or stolen.
label: BODY

text: •	 Use incognito or private browser tabs as often as possible.
label: BODY

text: Use antivirus/anti-malware software
label: HH1

text: •	 Make sure that you have appropriate antivirus/anti-malware software on all devices.
label: BODY

text: •	 Always check with an IT specialist in your office if available or otherwise with colleagues at a partner
label: BODY

text: organization to select the right tool and configure it appropriately.
label: BODY

text: 8   See the Guidance Note on Data Impact Assessment for additional information on how to conduct a DIA.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: OCTOBER 2022
label: BODY

text: Keep software and operating systems up to date
label: BODY

text: •	 Check regularly that your device, software, applications, and browser plug-ins are up to date and enable
label: BODY

text: automatic updates for your operating system.
label: BODY

text: •	 Use web browsers that receive automatic security updates.
label: BODY

text: •	 Avoid the use of software for which future maintenance is likely not to be available.
label: BODY

text: •	 Shut down devices regularly or when prompted by your system to enable updating and protect against
label: BODY

text: attacks.
label: BODY

text: Avoid phishing scams and be careful what you click
label: HH1

text: •	 When receiving suspicious emails or other messages, always check the sender's address/contact
label: BODY

text: information and only click on links or attachments from trusted senders.
label: BODY

text: •	 Even if the link is from a trusted sender, always copy it and use a private or incognito browser tab to
label: BODY

text: open it.
label: BODY

text: •	 Always check that the URL corresponds to a known, reputable website by running it through a search
label: BODY

text: engine to ensure the website is legitimate.
label: BODY

text: •	 Hover over a URL link before clicking it to see where the link is actually taking you.
label: BODY

text: •	 Do not reply to suspicious emails or forward them to your colleagues.
label: BODY

text: •	 Report any suspicious activity through the appropriate channel within your organization.
label: BODY

text: Use mobile devices responsibly
label: HH1

text: •	 Use separate devices for work purposes wherever possible. Keep your work devices in a secure place at
label: BODY

text: all times and avoid carrying them around unnecessarily.
label: BODY

text: •	 Use messaging tools approved by your organization that provide end-to-end encryption.
label: BODY

text: •	 Minimize the use of Bluetooth connectivity and location services, and turn them off when possible.
label: BODY

text: •	 Use a Virtual Private Network (VPN) when working online. Consult the IT department or your colleagues
label: BODY

text: for a list of approved tools.
label: BODY

text: •	 Always sign out of your account(s) if you are using a public/shared computer or device.
label: BODY

text: •	 Do not access sensitive services or information on public/shared devices unless absolutely necessary.
label: BODY

text: •	 Disable biometric unlock features—particularly when in transit.
label: BODY

text: •	 Verify that your device does not track activity or content and disable those functions where possible.
label: BODY

text: Practice data minimization
label: HH1

text: •	 Only collect the minimum amount of data required to achieve the objective and purposes for a given
label: BODY

text: data management activity.
label: BODY

text: •	 Only retain sensitive data when strictly necessary and for as long as necessary to fulfill the purpose for
label: BODY

text: which it is being managed and as required by applicable guidance, law and regulations.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: OCTOBER 2022
label: BODY

text: 9   The IASC Data Asset Registry template is available here.
label: BODY

text: 10 The IASC Information Sharing Protocol template is available here.
label: BODY

text: 11   See for example the Data and Information Sensitivity Classification for Ukraine.
label: BODY

text: COLLABORATORS: PRIVACY INTERNATIONAL; YALE UNIVERSITY, JACKSON INSTITUTE OF GLOBAL AFFAIRS.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’), together with key partners, is publishing a series of guidance
label: BODY

text: notes and tip sheets on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2022 and 2023. The
label: BODY

text: guidance note series continues work initiated in 2019 and 2020. It also complements the Inter-Agency Standing
label: BODY

text: Committee Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action and the OCHA Data
label: BODY

text: Responsibility Guidelines, which were published in February 2021 and October 2021 respectively. Through
label: BODY

text: the series, the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in practice. The guidance notes and tip sheets published in 2022-2023 have been made possible
label: BODY

text: with the support of the Government of Switzerland.
label: BODY

text: Safeguard sensitive data
label: BODY

text: •	 Transfer and store data using approved tools and channels (locally on an internal server, computer or
label: BODY

text: laptop, or on servers and systems operated by your organization, using end-to-end encryption).
label: BODY

text: •	 Password protect and/or encrypt files (Word, Excel, PDF) containing sensitive data and share document
label: BODY

text: passwords through separate channels (i.e., text a password for an emailed document).
label: BODY

text: •	 Limit and carefully monitor the number of people with access to sensitive data.
label: BODY

text: •	 Define a retention and destruction schedule for all data managed by your organization and use
label: BODY

text: appropriate tools for the destruction of data.
label: BODY

text: •	 Do not discuss sensitive information in public settings and ensure that no unauthorized persons have
label: BODY

text: access to your meeting spaces, both physical and online.
label: BODY

text: •	 Encrypt your email messages.
label: BODY

text: •	 Maintain a Data Asset Registry9 that indicates the level of sensitivity for each data type managed by
label: BODY

text: your office. Review sensitivity levels regularly as the context evolves.
label: BODY

text: •	 Consider developing a Data and Information Sensitivity Classification for your context, either as part of
label: BODY

text: an Information Sharing Protocol10 or as a standalone document for reference.11
label: BODY

text: Organizational investment in data security
label: HH1

text: Beyond the individual actions outlined above, data security requires broad, organization-level engagement.
label: BODY

text: Organizations need to invest in data security measures to promote data responsibility across their
label: BODY

text: offices and teams. This might include adopting relevant policies and guidelines, risk-related mitigation
label: BODY

text: procedures, investing human and financial resources in data security and management, and promoting data
label: BODY

text: responsibility among staff and partners.
label: BODY
